entries.text: Written by Paul McNamara and published on Network World.
entries.title: Perl programming language turns 25 today

entries.author: mark_keating
entries.text: Mark Keating published this on The Perl Foundation web site.
entries.title: The First Twenty-Five Years

entries.text: Woody Leonhard InfoWorld (also on Javaworld).
entries.title: The Perl programming language turns 25

entries.text: The Register by Neil McAllister.
entries.title: Perl programming language marks 25th birthday

entries.text: More than 150 comments and of course many of them are negative.
entries.title: Reddit / programming

entries.text: By Jon Biggs at TechCrunch.
entries.title: print 'Happy 25th Birthday, Perl';

entries.text: Bradley M. Kuhn compares how he looked at COBOL programmers when he was young and COBOL was 25 years old, to how young people look at Perl programmers today when Perl is 25 years old. Can those really be compared?
entries.title: Perl is Free Software's COBOL, and That's Ok!

entries.text: Silicon India
entries.title: Perl, The Hackers' Favorite Language Celebrates 25th Birthday

entries.text: The H Open
entries.title: Perl passes the 25 year mark

entries.text: Michal Wojciechowski celebrated with a one liner ... try it for yourself if you run Linux or OSX. (I think this would not work Windows.) The code is explained in the comments!
entries.title: Happy Birthday Perl

entries.author: andrew_shitov
entries.text: Andrew Shitov shared his personal story with Perl and his love for the language and the community around it.
entries.title: The Joy of Perl

chapters.footer: If you know about other articles or discussions, please let me know so I can share them in the next issue.
chapters.header: Perl turned 25 on 18th December. There were a number of articles and blogs posts about it, and it was discussed on a number of forums. Let me share a bunch with you:
chapters.title: Perl is 25 years old

entries.text: There are a couple of ways to deal with circular references. chromatic shows how to break them manually.
entries.title: Improve Your Extracted Traversal

entries.author: viacheslav_tykhanovskyi
entries.text: Design by Contract is a programming approach when method calls are checked against specific requirements by embedded in the language or implemented as a library functions. Viacheslav Tykhanovskyi (vti) describes several ways to do this in Perl and when to avoid this approach.
entries.title: Design by contract in Perl

entries.author: david_golden
entries.text: David Golden was designing a password reset system for his Dancer based web application.
entries.title: My second week of Dancer, now with queues and transactional email

entries.author: curtis_ovid_poe
entries.text: Ovid has started to build a module for testing applications using Moose.
entries.title: Test::Class + Moose?

entries.author: john_napiorkowski
entries.text: While sitting at a MacDonalds and working, John Napiorkowski, arrived to the conclusion that if he wants to be able to get people excited by Perl, he needs to be able to show things that get immediate and fancy results.
entries.title: It Happened At MacDonalds, A Meditation

entries.text: Christopher Frenz provides a simple tool in Perl to compare the resolved IP addresses received from by DNS servers. This can be a nice tool for system administrator who has just changed the IP address of a machine and would like to check if the change has already reached those servers.
entries.title: Comparing DNS Requests with Perl

entries.author: yanick_champoux
entries.text: tie is powerful but strange tool in Perl that only people like Yanick Champoux should touch. Indeed he used it while visiting his favorite Himalayan barbershop.
entries.title: Fit To Be tied (tied handles and localized $\)

entries.text: The shorts story of Chisel wanting to send a message to his Android device and ending up as a co-maintainer of WebService::NotifyMyAndroid.
entries.title: Notify Your Android?

entries.text: Reading this article you will learn how to use the MetaCPAN::API to fetch information about a single module or about a distribution on CPAN.
entries.title: How to fetch the CPAN dependency tree of a Perl module?

entries.text: January 11-13, 2013, Orlando, Florida, USA
entries.title: 2013 Perl Oasis conference, Orlando, Florida

entries.text: February 24-25, 2013, Tel Aviv, Israel
entries.title: Israeli Perl-Workshop 2013 (ILPW)

entries.text: March 13-15, 2013, Berlin, Germany
entries.title: German Perl-Workshop 2013

chapters.header: I usually list the next 3-4 events here. The list of all the events can be found on the web site. If your Perl event is not listed there, please let me know.
chapters.title: Events

header: I am sure most of you are spending the next few days enjoying your family, and other loved ones, but maybe you will have a few minutes here and there to check e-mail and read about Perl too.
There is a collection of links from the 25th birthday of Perl and a few other links too.
subject: Perl is 25 years old (and Merry Christmas too :)
